Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Australia
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Gordon Ober of the University of Rhode Island to conduct a research project, entitled "Impacts of Climate Change on Tropical Marine Algae," during the summer of 2012 at Griffith University in Nathan, Queensland, Australia. The host scientist is Dr. Guillermo Diaz-Pulido.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project comes from investigating the effects of increased ocean acidification and temperature on the ecology of a tropical marine algal species that compete with coral species on Australia's Great Barrier Reef. Ocean acidification and ocean warming are significant components of global climate change, and understanding how organisms respond to these changes is important to understanding how ecosystems may function under new climatic conditions. As the base of the food web, changes in growth and productivity of primary producers can have cascading effects throughout higher trophic levels, thereby potentially altering ecosystem assemblages and shifting community structure from coral-dominated to algal-dominated systems.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. This research investigates how acidification alters coral reef ecosystems. Reefs are economically important in many countries. Coral reefs such as the Great Barrier Reef are magnets for eco-tourism and are sometimes the largest source of income for local communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As climate change continues to tighten its grip on earth it is becoming increasingly important to understand how organisms and ecosystems will respond. Ocean acidification has become a hot topic in climate change research over the past few years. As atmospheric CO2 continues to rise, more CO2 is dissolving into ocean waters. Through chemical reactions with water, the increases in CO2 are causing the water to become more acidic. Most of the existing work focuses on how calcifying organisms will respond. However, all organisms as well as communities are likely to be impacted by acidification.

 

 I headed to Australia as an NSF EAPSI Fellow to work at Griffith University with Dr. Guillermo Diaz-Pulido investigating how acidification was affecting one of the most diverse and fragile ecosystems, coral reefs. My research, however, did not focus on coral. I joined an existing project that investigated the response of non-calcifying macroalgae to increased acidification. I looked specifically at how turf algal communities were impacted by different levels of CO2. Turf algae are small communities of algae comprised of a number of species that are diverse in morphology and life history. They play an important role in reef ecosystems as a source of food and in nutrient cycling.

 

I analyzed preserved turf algal communities growing on pieces of coral rubble under control, medium, and high CO2 treatments. My analysis was done post-treatment and was divided into two phases. In the first phase I took dimensional measurements of the coral rubble and removed (by scraping) half of the turf algal community. Wet mass of the turf was recorded and the sample was placed in a drying oven. Dry mass was recorded after 24 hours in the oven and the sample was then placed into a muffle furnace to burn off carbon-based tissue. This allowed me to determine the organic content of the turf community. This process was done for 31 total samples. Mass measurements were standardized to a mg/cm2 unit and results were compared by treatment.

 

In the second phase, I removed a small section of turf algae from each sample and mounted it onto a microscope slide. Using a compound microscope, the slides were analyzed for genera present. Once the present genera had been identified, 5 randomly chosen fields of view were selected and the relative abundance of each genus was determined. This process was completed for all 31 samples. Results were combined and compared by treatment.

 

The results from both phases told the same story. Turf algal communities are resilient with increases in CO2. There were no significant differences in biomass of turfs based on treatment. There was also no significant difference in the number of genera present or the breakdown of algal divisions present. While these results are not flashy they do support some existing thoughts in acidification. Primary producers, like turf algae, need CO2 for photosynthesis in order for growth and productivity. With excess CO2 these organisms are expected to thrive and in some cases take over ecosystems.

 

My return to the United States was met by family, after the initial shock of seeing everyone my dad posed a question to me: “so what did you get out of this trip?” I thought for a moment about my research and collaborations. My experience in Australia was not limited to research. Taking advantage of every moment of free time allowed me to explore Australia, meet interesting people, and become part of a community. I was able to experience typical tourist things like seeing the Great Barrier Reef, surfing, encountering koalas and kangaroos, and hiking rainforests.
